column2: 45-54 on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $1$1$1$I began Cymbalta and approx. 4 weeks in I began having diarrhea.  I thought it was a virus and waited 10 days and then went to my doctor.  I discussed with her the only change that I had was the Cymbalta.  She didn't think that it was the cause and so I remained on the drug.  2 weeks later I still had the diarrhea so I was referred to a gastroenterologist.  They did a colonoscopy and said it initially looked healthy.  A week or so later they called me and told me that I had Lymphocytic Colitis.  One of the first things she said to me was that she noticed I was on Cymbalta.  I told her say nothing more because I was already in the middle of weaning myself off because I felt like it had to be the issue.  She said yes they have found that it can cause this. So you think ok problem solved
column3: but Lymphocytic Colitis cannot be cured.  I am now under control but only because I take Budesonide 3mg daily.  It was a miserable existence without it
column4: and don't say why don't you try gluten free
column5: or no dairy... I have tried it all.  My 2nd opinion Gastroenterologist said
column6: our patients with this have also tried everything
column7: just take the pill. Why in an otherwise healthy person
column8: exercise regularly eat healthy would it do this... I don't know but I am obviously not the only one!

column2: 75 or over Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I am not a doctor.  I am a sick old man. I have been taking Cymbalta 30 mg for several years as a component of my daily medication cocktail. It is virtually impossible to determine or rate the effectiveness of a drug like this when you are taking eight to ten (or more) other medications which deal with contiguous medical conditions.  The side effects of every drug cross the side effects of another drug being prescribed to a patient by a different doctor for a different medical condition.  Sounds confusing and it is.  However
column3: with respect to Cymbalta
column4: I will say this.  When I first began taking the drug
column5: I noticed a definite improvement in my pertinent symptoms.  I have been taking it for several years now at a low dosage and I have continued to notice its effectiveness with no negative side effects.  In short
column6: it has continued to work for me
column7: and in this sense I endorse it.  However
column8: I consider myself lucky because medications such as Cymbalta are prescribed by many doctors who are not sufficiently checking the side effects of parenthetic drugs which his or her patients take. This is particularly the case when some of those medications in a patient's chart have been prescribed by other doctors for other medical conditions.  I suspect that even routine  pharmacology  can be a very dangerous crap game when it is played by too many doctors who have forgotten some of the basic clinical skills they learned in med school.

column1: 13$Major Depressive Disorder$12/15/2018 8:29:01 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$1$5$"This is honestly the worst drug anyone could ever take. I took 60mg of Duloxetine for over 5 years and had to come off it for surgery.
I was initially prescribed it by a psychiatrist and left on it for so long because my GPs didn’t know what it was or what it did. Admittedly
column2: it did the job and helped a lot with my depression and anxiety
column3: but it wasn’t worth it for the withdrawal symptoms I suffered with.

column1: Do not take this drug long term - you will never be able to come off it. The withdrawal is absolutely horrendous. I actually thought I was having a seizure at one point. I had absolutely no choice but to come off it because it isn’t available in liquid form. If I wasn’t having surgery
column2: I’d have taken it again in an instant to stop the awful withdrawal effects.

column1: I have been reading lots about this drug and feel I have to warn people. There have been many lawsuits against the manufacturer because coming off it is likened to coming off speed. The withdrawal can last years for some people.

I can’t even describe how awful it is trying to come off this drug. I honestly thought I was going to die. I had flashes of electricity through my brain every couple of minutes that rendered me totally unable to do anything. My head was fuzzy
column2: I had awful dreams and sweats
column3: I had stomach upsets and just a terrible feeling of paranoia.

column1: I have been off it for six months now and I was lucky that the withdrawal effects stopped after around 2 months.

column2: please
column3: please be aware before taking this drug - stopping it was one of the hardest things I’ve ever done in my life. I wish I’d known about it before I started taking it. "

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month$1$1$1$"After approx. 1 wk on Cymbalta
column3: major episode of rt. hand swelling twice the size
column4: fingers w/ no feeling
column5: brown/red/blue ""leather-looking"" skin with a large
column6: pulsating lump that appeared in the center of the hand
column7: stretching the skin as it grew before my eyes within 10 minutes! A very dangerous drug with 35+ side effects that people don't know about unless they search to find real-life experiences & studies done not only in the U.S.
column8: but other countries. This lasted 2-1/2 wks; there are reported experiences of swelling of the THROAT in which you must get medical attention immediately--I was ""lucky"" & immediately stopped using. People should always research (on sites other than the drug's site) all possible side effects & consider asking for something far less invasive. My hand literally looked like a monkey's paw & was Not Usable for weeks. I still do not see this particular reporting in the advertisement literature--just ""swelling."" That is an understatement. Be your own best advocate so you will lower the incidence of some of these frightening results. Many of the anti-depressant drugs/anxiety stay in your system even after you stop. Take time to read what other people have experienced & less on ""a few people experienced..."" in ads. I had no prior history of anything of this nature
column9: so it can happen to anyone. There are many excellent drugs (older drugs) that work much better under supervision. Thank you."

I have been on 60 mg for over 3 years now and I think more positive and hope anyone who is in a state of depression to keep trying to find the right combination to help you get out of the black hole. 385$Major Depressive Disorder$10/20/2014 3:04:42 PM$Reviewer: Elise, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $3$1$3$this drug helped my depression at the expense of my emotional capacity. no empathy, poor judgement and heavy drinking. Physical impact included high blood pressure, heavy weight gain leading to high cholesterol, and the inability to empty my bladder leading to chronic UIT's. I did a gradual taper under my psychiatrist's guidance and went through a devastating withdrawal from which i still have not recovered over 5 months later. developed serious symptoms I never had previous to taking cymbalta including disabling anxiety.   do not let anyone tell you it is the depression coming back. this happens to people who took it for pain and had no history of depression. the black box warning mentions risk of suicidal thoughts. it happens when increasing and decreasing your dose. do not let a doctor tell you that you need anti-depressants for life. get good cognitive behavioral therapy. research shows it works better than drugs and i am living proof. now that i quit, i am active, lost weight, now my bmi is 20. no more High BP and cholesterol is 95.

687$Major Depressive Disorder$9/6/2013 10:43:02 AM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$5$5$I have been on Cymbalta at 60mg for 3 months and so far I think it's wonderful. Before this I was on Pristique and I would have episodes of uncontrollable crying and anxiety. I weaned off it for about 3 weeks before getting on Cymbalta and that was an awful thing to go through. Cymbalta helped me right away. Cymbalta has helped me feel more like myself and I can go on with my normal daily activities. Pristique and other anti-depressants have made me feel foggy. Cymbalta does not do this to me. I've had trouble sleeping with other medicines and with cymbalata I occasionally wake up in the middle of the night to go to the bathroom but then fall right back asleep. I'm not so sure if that is a direct relation to the medication or not. I also have bad gas occasionally (not uncontrollable, just stinky) but i'm not sure if it is a side affect and if it is it is very minor compared to the benefits. I haven't experienced any weight gain/loss and I follow a healthy diet. Cymbalta is working for me but won't work for everyone. Pristique was horrible for me but is great for others. Depression is caused by a chemical imbalance in the brain (in most cases) and everyone is different. So I encourage you to try it and keep trying until you find the right one.

45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$2$2$Cymbalta did help my depression/anxiety problems and may have helped my muscle pain but it gave me a rash.  I got small round red patches that skin would crust over like a scab and flake off of and if I did not use clotrimizole on it
column3: it got redder and redder til it would bleed.  It itched and was painful. Unfortunately
column4: the cause wasn't obvious
column5: and for years I suffered with this. I went to 4 dermatologists who acted like they knew just what it was but their prescription didn't work. They all said not to use clomitrizole but it was my only relief. Finally
column6: Dr. tried to increase my dose of cymbalta from 30 to 60
column7: and then to 90 and the rash was worse than ever
column8: and the lightbulb finally went on above my head. I stopped taking cymbalta very gradually because it reeked havoc with my stomache with each tiny bit I decreased. The rash was gone for the first time in years I didn't have one of those painful itchy spots.  I was without the rash for 3 months when my depression problems came back. I tried cymbalta again and the rash came back worse than ever.  I hope this helpful to anyone with skin problems of any kind. Test for yourself and don't put all your faith in doctors telling you it has nothing to do with your meds. And read side effects and warnings in more than one place. I had to read a lot of info til I found the warning in small print to discontinue if you get a skin flaming rash. I should have run across that warning a lot sooner.

1100$Major Depressive Disorder$8/12/2012 8:36:04 AM$Reviewer: DLMCD1966, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $2$1$1$I had a quack psychiatrist prescribe a maximum  manufactures suggested dosage of this drug and it was within manufacturers guideline but I felt like this doctor was getting some sort of kick backs from drug companies or something to kick expensive drugs because he would never prescribe a generic and he took me off drugs that worked and put me on drugs like this that did not work.  I have been bipolar for years and have used many drugs and this is the worst of all of them.  One night I started getting really confused while doing my job as a route delivery driver to retail stores.  I called my father who is elderly because I did not know what else to do and I was confused.  He called my employer and took me to the hospital.  It struck me as odd right off the bat that they put me in a room with a person with liver failure?  Then finally after days of testing a group of 4 doctors visited me before I was released and gave me the diagnosis.  I had hepatic encephalopothy  or water on the brain from a liver problem they claimed was caused by this drug.  While I made a full recovery I must say that when they say on the television ""liver problems sometimes fatal"" have been reported they mean it.  Of course the original prescribing doctor wanted to argue with the diagnosis of the 4 hospital doctors and I told him off and fired him in a dramatic way.  Now after years on meds for bipolar I must say I think this is the most dangerous drug I have ever taken and I cannot urge people enough to try other options before trying this drug.  Water on your brain is a sign of a failing liver and my doctors insist that this drug caused it. Thankfully there has been no permanent damage that is showing and my liver function tests are back in normal range.  I am afraid of this drug.   "

column3: i realized what i was experiencing was typical. i took 30mg at 5pm along with gabapentin 600m & celebrex (have taken for 2 yrs. went to bed @10 & woke up at 1am with severe nausea. sat up
column4: felt very dizzy
column5: weird
column6: confused. felt very hot & sweaty like a hot flash i had on tamaxofin (breast cancer drug) but a months worth at one time! i panicked
column7: felt sick so went to bathroom. had diarrhea. my head started to feel weird like i was out of body. my eyes felt weird & i tried to look at myself but couldn't focus in mirror. i was scared. made it back to bed
column8: husband asked if i was ok
column9: mumbled mmmm
column10: because i felt like i couldn't speak-he went back to sleep. i sat on the edge of bed
column11: i felt like i couldn't sit still but at the same time couldn't move my body only my eyes. still felt hot& panicky. my heart didn't feel like it was racing so i calmed myself down
column12: after @20mins i was able to calm down& felt myself cooling down. i was afraid it would start again. finally laid back down & laid awake 2 hrs feeling dizzy
column13: scared & like i was out of my body. after 2 hrs fell asleep & woke up at 5:15 w/husband & told him what happened. when i woke up i felt weird
column14: foggy & went back to sleep for another 2 hrs. woke up less foggy but still so. it's 1pm 12 hrs later & i still don't feel right. it was so scary & bizarre. hard to believe it happened. i'm getting ready to report this to my doctor & FDA. i won't be taking this drug after this one & only time. never had a reaction to any med so i was suprised this happened. so thankful for all of you that have reported on the affects of this drug
column15: for without that i would have been at the emergancy room last pm thinking i was literally ready to die. i felt like someone had tranqualized me & i would pass out. my advice is to stay calm & try to ride the affects out
column16: & notify DR asap.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $3$1$1$"I had been on Cymbalta for chronic depression for little over a year. A few days ago one morning I was about to get out of bed and all of a sudden I heard a sound like quickly letting air from a balloon. column3: weak with severe pressure. Oh yeah I have RA
column4: Fibromyalgia and a pinched nerve in my neck[worse on right side]. I was admitted in the hospital because they wanted to run tests[ CT
column5: 3 MRI tests
column6: Ultrasound on my neck & heart]to see if maybe I was having a stroke or aneurysm. My mom died [49 yrs old]from an aneurysm and my older sister had 2 aneurysms that was caught in time to have surgery. After all the tests they could not find anything which I am so very glad to know because I had been telling my PCP & my husband that there is something wrong in my brain. I am no longer on Cymbalta but this episode of ""brain zaps"" really scared me. I pray that if anyone that reads this review and are having symptons such as this please tell your PCP so you can be weaned off this drug. I was weaned from 1[20mg]capsule 2 times a day to 1 time a day until I was finally taken off. My experience with Cymbalta has been very very very SCARY. "

In the beginning I had only minor side effects and they went away after a few weeks. The one side effect that has never gone away is a slight upset stomach right after swallowing the pills. I think this is due to the fact that the pills float. It takes a little getting used to swallowing floating pills. Overall I am very happy with this medicine. It has been the best medicine for me that I have ever tried. I also financially qualify for patient asisstance from the manufacturer so I get my medicine with no charge. Just a few forms to fill out. There is no, one-right-medicine-for-everyone, out there so if you try this medicine and it doesn't work for you just keep trying with your doctor to find one that does. I've tried ones that seem to have no effect and others that make me soooooo sick I think I'm dying I'm in so much pain. Cymbalta has worked for me and I intend to continue taking it for a long time.

1542$Major Depressive Disorder$8/30/2011 3:23:19 AM$Reviewer: slrs87, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $3$3$5$I was diagnosed with bipolar II approximately 18 months ago and I started taking Cymbalta approximately 1 year ago. To begin with it was extremely helpful with my moods and general feelings of depression. It has now become less affective and I am looking for an alternative. I experienced the normal symptoms of feeling like I would vomit (but never did) for approximately 8 months that subsided eventually. I also get what is referred to as 'serotonin' dreams where I have extremely vivid and life like dreams due to this antid. I hate this of course as it often leaves me waking up wondering if I recovered a memory instead of knowing I have just had another dream. This disheartens me greatly as I lived with depression for a number of years due to previously trying a number of antid's and getting hideous side effects until I tried Cymbalta. Now I am only left with the choice to see a psychiatrist to use me as a lab rat to test different drugs as no doctor ever knows exactly how you will react to a certain drug and the side effects you may have. Please don't let what I have written freak you out I just believe that knowledge is power and hope that maybe I could help someone. Thanks, good luck and never stop trying to love yourself. Sarah (Mackay)

However I have noticed a few negative side affects...prior to taking cymbalta I never had anxiety now I get it quite often and have had many anxiety/panic attacks. My over all health has gone down in last few years...about 30 pounds of weight gain, high blood pressure, and severe migrane attacks (never had those prior either), and more recently hypothyroidism. Not positive these things are related to the cymbalta use but deffintly the aniexty and migranes. The absolute worst part of cymbalta is attempting to wean off of it. I have made a few attempts, this last time I gradually wean down over a period of 4 months. I got all the way down to only 20mg every other day, but the withdrawls were unbearable! Yes, physically painful in muscle's and joint's as well as terrible migranes and vertigo, mood swings, and anxiety. I feel like I'm a prisoner to cymbalta, I hate it...and regret the day I agreed with my doctor to begin use. Before beginning cymbalta do research on the side effects and withdrawl symptoms of going off...I wish I did! My doctor now tells me it is one of the hardest anti-depressants to quit.

column4: in the same place everytime.  I did miss two days at one time and felt very bad. I was dizzy and felt tingly in my face. All stopped when I returned home and took my forgotten medicine.  I when I was taking the 30mg daily
column5: that it worked better for me. That could have just been because I was starting to feel better though.  I haven't had any sexual side effects
column6: no abnormal sweating
column7: or anger issues with this drug. I am concentrating more and i work better. I do have aches and pains from the depression that seem to be easing. I will continue to report progress.  [email protected]"

35-44 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $3$1$2$"Was prescribed this drug for depression and had a rough adjustment period. Took 30mg for a week
column3: during which time I was nauseous
column4: dizzy
column5: and suffered some of the worst headaches of my life.  Increased to 60mg after that
column6: and began to feel better mentally.  I actually could get through a day at work without bursting into tears for no reason
column7: and I started feeling moments of happiness again.  The side effects during this time however were quite irritating.  I began to bite the inside of my mouth during sleep
column8: and sometimes when awake and not even when eating! I ended up with painful mouth ulcers from repeated biting
column9: and this lasted about a month after switching to the 60mg. I then began experiencing insomnia at night
column10: and bouts of nearly narcoleptic drowsiness at work
column11: along with shortness of breath and vertigo.  Then I got on the scale and realized with horror that I had gained 20 pounds!!! I had already gained 15 pounds in the 8 months prior to taking the medication.  I am willing to accept responsibility for THOSE pounds
column12: because I sat home and ate like a pig for weeks after the suicide of my sister.  I was NOT prepared to gain 20 pounds in 3 months while working and eating healthfully.  The shock of being a 5'4"" female who now weighs close to 175 pounds was enough to send me into a three week drinking binge. So much for the few months of feeling slightly better.  I am now debating on whether or not to quit taking this medication
column13: as some reviewers have suggested that it may cause further weight gain.  I am not prepared to deal with that
column14: and I really wish they would list weight gain as a side effect on the patient info! I would NEVER have agreed to take this medication if I had known it were a possibility.  In summary
column15: the damage that this medication has caused to my self esteem and my sex life are likely irreversible and I was probably less depressed before Cymbalta than I am right now."

column11: and Pamelor.  In most cases
column12: either the side effects were intolerable or there was something ""missing."" When I began treatment with Cymbalta
column13: something clicked - and it felt wonderful.  Over the past couple of years
column14: I've been on/off it due to insurance b.s.  A little over two months ago
column15: I resumed taking Cymbalta 60mg/day.  My depression began to lift within two-three weeks
column16: then after a month
column17: my fibromyalgia symptoms decreased and my chronic back pain is GONE.

column1: The only side effects I've noticed are: very mild decrease in libido (hence only 4/5 stars on ease of use)
column2: a bit of sweating
column3: and occasionally a tad of urinary hesitation.  I'm guessing that Cymbalta has just the right balance of serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibition. (unlike most other SNRIs)

column1: Though it can be a bit pricey depending on your insurance
column2: I believe it is well worth it. Honestly
column3: I would recommend this medication to anyone- especially to those who have not responded to SSRIs and also those who suffer from the double-whammy of depression and a chronic pain syndrome.

2101$Major Depressive Disorder$8/7/2010 1:12:19 AM$Reviewer: Wloosue, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $1$1$4$It was a nightmare!  I lost my short-term memory, had severely stiff muscles and cramping, increased depression, intolerable insomnia, sugar cravings like you wouldn't believe (with related weight gain), joint pain, heart palpitations, tinnitus, hypertension, no libido, no motivation to do anything.  They don't give you enough information on side effects.  I didn't know I was having side effects until I found this web site.  I spent a month weaning myself off and felt dramatically better - like I have my life back. I actually started sleeping a little.  After  a month I threw the rest of my pills away and have been having some withdrawal.  It takes a while to get this poison out of your system, I guess.  The joint pain and muscle cramping are worse.  I feel a lot of intense, irrational anger, still have heart palpitations, tinnitus and hypertension.  At least I can sleep.  I made the decision to get off this stuff without consulting my dr. My experience with drs. is that they want to increase the dosage or add another pill to combat side effects rather than support a patient becoming drug free.  If depression becomes a problem in the future, I'll try a more natural approach to treating  it.  Right now, despite the withdrawal symptoms, I feel pretty terrific - better than I have felt in years.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $3$2$1$I have been on Cymbalta for 5 yrs.  It will help with depression somewhat (as well as any other antidep) BUT the side effects far outweigh benefits.  The only reason I have taken so long is that it's extremely difficult to stop....Some other users ask if fast heartbeat
column3: anxious
column4: is normal with this med...that is actually a withdrawl symptom specific to Cymbalta. Problem is that it is so short acting that if you forget the dose or take it much later than the day before
column5: these syptoms will start immediately.  So users think its a side effect. There are many bad effects when first taking....but when they go away
column6: and your body becomes tolerant then med also slowly stops working....so after the first year you are really just taking med for no reason. Never heard anyone say it actually helps pain...I am transitioning to another med...not easy
column7: but did realise that syptoms I had for so long are now going away
column8: like sleepiness
column9: uncaring
column10: energy loss...and sex is now amazing...so MY advise is...only start this med if: the cost and doctor visits to get right dosage are not an issue
column11: you are militant about taking meds on time
column12: you are not in a relationship or care about sexual side effects
column13: you don't require much energy or concentration throughout the day
column14: and will be able to handle the pain if you ever have to stop taking med.

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $3$2$4$I've lived most of my life with a severe panic disorder. column3: it gave me energy I felt great

column5: I was tired physically and mentally
column6: I started getting bran zaps
column7: sometimes slurred speech
column8: confusion or brain fog
column9: and I could feel the anxiety slowly creeping back in the picture. So my doctor switched me over to Prozac however getting off of Cymbalta is no easy task! You experience horrible withdrawal symptoms such as: horrible physical pain and weakness
column10: brain fog
column11: uncontrollable muscle tremors
column12: extreme nausea
column13: feelings of being lost or out of place
column14: intense periods of depression and crying
column15: heart palpitations
column16: dizziness
column17: extreme anger
column18: migraines
column19: and the list goes on. To say the least
column20: it's no cake walk and you probably will slip and take one just for a break in the withdrawal symptoms but be strong and stay at it and the symptoms will slowly subside. I finally stopped having withdrawal symptoms about 2 months after stopping Cymbalta. I implore anyone researching Cymbalta to try Prozac first; I've been on it for about a year and a half now and couldn't be happier. I hope this helps! Always remember you're not alone in this and stay positive. Never give up hope
column21: life is beautiful behind the veil of depression and anxiety. Tomorrow the sun will rise and bring with it a new day with many new possibilities :) God bless!

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $2$1$5$"I saw the ads for this medication and thought it sounded like the best thing since sliced bread.   I looked it up online and decided that it would be safe enough
column3: hassle-free enough
column4: and so I asked my doctor for a prescription.

column2: I noticed that I was getting small lumps under my skin -- about a dozen of them -- that seemed to be growing kind of fast.  I didn't associate it with Cymbalta
column3: they didn't actually hurt
column4: and I had a follow-up appointment with my doctor in about a month
column5: so I didn't do anything.

column2: we discovered a lump in my breast
column3: on my chest wall and immovable.  Needless to say
column4: I went to the doctor right away.   He said he didn't know the cause of any of the bumps
column5: but got me a referral to a surgeon right away for the one in my breast.

column1: I had the lump removed -- went through the risk of surgery with general anesthesia.  The cytology showed that the lump was not cancer
column2: but a lipoma -- a cyst of fat.

column1: I looked up every one of my meds online
column2: read every single possible problem with them.  Lo and behold one of the things Cymbalta could do was cause lipomas.  I  took myself off of it
column3: tapered off.

column1: That was all about 4 years ago.   I still have the other lumps
column2: though they might be marginally smaller. "

45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $3$3$5$I switched from Effexor to Cymbalta because I still didn't feel as positive as I wanted to. Initially
column3: it worked pretty well. However
column4: over time it was just like the Effexor. I had gone off Effexor in the past and suffered only minor feelings of restlessness
column5: anxiety
column6: sweating and some nausea. Not so with Cymbalta. I ran out
column7: and within 4 days of having weaned myself off (I went from 120 mg to 60 to 0)
column8: began feeling such despair and hopelessness. I was sweating profusely
column9: felt disoriented - like I didn't belong anywhere
column10: crying
column11: my entire body began to spasm. I vomited (severe
column12: wretched) for 3 days. I couldn't even keep water down. I became dehydrated. I was shaking and shivering so hard my teeth rattled. I now have an idea what a junkie must feel like when detoxing from Heroin. I felt like a complete zombie. I have never felt so horrible in all my life. Whatever you do
column13: DO NOT stop using Cymbalta unless you're in the hospital or have a health care professional in your home. I went back on Cymbalta as soon as I found someone to go to the pharmacy. There was no alternative. It would appear that I'll be taking this medication for the rest of my life. I can't go through the withdrawals agan. No way. I lost 2 weeks of my life. I don't know what it's the pharmacological make-up of this drug is. How can it cause such horrific symptoms when your body is deproved of it when it really doesn't work all that great?

column1: One thing that I want anyone considering Cymbalta to know is that the Discontinuation Syndrome for this drug is horrendous. I'm slowly tapering off of Cymbalta right now and it's been the worst experience of my life. I feel like my body is shutting down. I've been incredibly nauseous

column1: Really weigh the pros and cons when considering Cymbalta as an option. Even if this drug does work for your depression (or other needs)

column3: think about the discontinuation side effects because
column4: personally and without being too dramatic

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$4$3$"PLEASE READ THIS IF YOU'RE COMING OFF CYMBALTA!  There are some real horror stories on here.  I had a great Dr. managing my meds...I was very concerned about withdrawal side effects
column3: so we took over 3 months to get me off it after I was ""done"" (I was on it for 1 yr after it had started working to make sure I did not relapse after coming off).  Don't rush!  If you rush
column4: you get bad side effects.  I started at 60mg and went down 10mg every 2 weeks.  Near the end she had me open the 20mg capsule
column5: dump about half the contents out and reclose capsule and take it.  Then I took about 1/4 capsule.  Then I went to 1/4 capsule every other day.  I started to get bad vertigo at one point
column6: so she had me step back to last dosage and start to decrease again once no side effects were there.  She also warned me that during withdrawal you can get what appears to be depression symptoms back (e.g. moodiness
column7: lack of patience
column8: crying for no reason
column9: etc).  I'm glad she did - otherwise I might have thought I needed to go back on it vs. it being a temporary thing while getting off the meds.  It took over 3 months
column10: but the process was a smooth one and I feel terrific.  Also - remember that people tend to read and write reviews on meds when they're experience isn't that great.  Most of these reviews sound terrible - but they are not a balanced view of what the med can do for you.  Most of the people with no problems won't have a reason to take the time to come on here.  Be patient with it!  If you have lots of withdrawal side effects
column11: talk to your Doc and slow the process down.  There's no reason you have to feel terrible through it all.  Cymbalta gave me my life back.  I am a better wife
column12: mother and friend after being on it.  I would do it all over again if I had to."

After going off of it for 5 weeks, I reluctantly went back on 30 mg for one week but she wants me on 60mg.  I have taken as much as 120mg while hospitalized but I was a zombie.  The decision of going back on Cymbalta or not is causing more suicidal thoughts/plans.  I thought this drug was supposed to help.  If I end up back in the hospital they will just force it into me as they did before.

column1: 3494$Major Depressive Disorder$1/12/2009 9:04:25 AM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $2$1$3$"I had been taking Cymbalta for approx. 1 year before deciding to stop using it.  I gained 35lbs+ while taking this medication.  The anxious feeling was increased while on this medication.  I finally went to a different doctor who actually listened to my complaints and agreed to help me wean myself off of it.  BEWARE!!!  The withdrawal symptoms are absolutely horrible.  It has been 2 months since I started the process of getting of the medicine.  There is a horribly scary feeling called ""brain zaps.""  Basically
column2: the neurotransmitters in your brain are fighting to find the Cymbalta it's so used to having...the result is that you feel incredibly dizzy and panicked.  The ""zaps"" occurred almost every minute.  The withdrawal symptoms were so bad.....I found myself relating to how drug addicts feel when they are ""coming down.""  Please talk with your doctor about the possible withdrawal symptoms.  Check out blogs of other people who have gone through the withdrawal.  Some day....the drug company may face a lawsuit.  "

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"I have been on Cymbalta for 3 years and have had no problems with side effects.  I have been treated for depression for 7 years and have tried over 5 medications during that time.  I was on prozac for a long time
column3: until the Prozac Poop-out hit and it no longer worked.  One of the frustrating things about depression and the way our bodies metabolize the medications is that the medication can stop working at any time & not all medications work on all people.  Some of the problems that people listed below
column4: I experience on other drugs.  For me Cymbalta is my miracle drug
column5: keeping me on an even keel with very few depressive episodes
column6: and even helping with my peripheral neuropathy (nerve damage) in my feet that I acquired from a chemo drug.  I am definately more ""ME"" on it.  No drug will work for all people or even forever.  If it doesn't work for you
column7: be persistant in looking for alternatives.  Work with a psychiatrist who knows all the medications/combinations available.  Don't take ""NO"" for an answer - only you know how you feel and only you will know when you have found the right drug.  Be your own health advocate or find someone to be one for you!  Best wishes to all for whom this doesn't work - keep pushing for the right drug - from someone who WILL BE on antidepresants for life!  (and not ashamed of it!) "

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$5$4$"One thing I've noticed
column3: using Cymbalta
column4: is that it clears the depressive thoughts and negative mentality
column5: so that I can realize and evaluate things in my life that aren't working.  For example
column6: I hate my job.  I now realize that hating my job contributes a great deal toward the depression and negative outlook that descends over me
column7: when the depression gets bad.  So
column8: is hating my job (since it takes up a huge part of my life) causing most of the depression?  And
column9: if I had a good
column10: great-paying job
column11: would I still get depressed and want to die?  I can't remember being caught up in severe depression the few times I've ever had jobs I loved.  At least now
column12: using Cymbalta
column13: I can take an evaluative look at my life
column14: instead of just wanting to die
column15: in order to stop feeling horrible.  Taking the drug clears my outlook enough to help me see that I need to make some changes.  Cymbalta helps me feel more able to move forward with my life
column16: and gives me the strength to work on positive change.  The depression episodes tend to play mind games with me.  During them
column17: it feels like everything is hopeless
column18: and I'm too worn down and tired to fight any longer.  Cymbalta is helping me see that's not really the truth about my reality.  Overall
column19: I guess it's worth risking the potentially dangerous side effects and/or withdrawal effects of this drug.  I'm thankful to feel better about my situation and my life.  This is the closest to normal I've felt
column20: other than the first little while I was on Prozac.  I've never been a ""happy"" person
column21: but at least Cymbalta helps me feel OK about it."

column10: I took it upon myself to discover what was going on. I scoured the internet until I came upon information documenting ""SSRI Discontinuation Syndrome."" I'm sure others here have commented on it
column11: because it apparently is not an isolated condition. It was a living hell
column12: and six months later
column13: although a different medication(Prozac) has helped
column14: I still feel the effects. It's a rare occurrence
column15: and I know how devastating depression is
column16: but take my advice and be careful before you use this or any other SSRI. And
column17: if you ultimately do decide upon Cymbalta
column18: make sure that you taper yourself of very gradually; the consequences are beyond what I ever imagined even on my worst days of depression. Be safe

column4: laughter with my wife and I've been off all medication for over a year.  That's the great thing.  I only needed to take the cymbalta for 3-4 months.

Nov 2007 I was prescribed cymbalta, early Dec it was increased to 60mg at night and 30mg in am.  Just before Christmas I awoke one morning - and was so happy to be alive. This has occurred, but never for any length of time, on and off in my life - but into the first week of June and regardless of outside influences which have been at times traumatic - I still wake up each day happy to be alive, a mood which stays with me until the next morning.  This medication in my opinion is the miracle I had been told by age 60 I would probably never see. The change in the subconscious mood from wishing to be dead into hoping to live until 100 so I can truly live life is one of the 3 most important things that is in my life- the other two being my adult children. column3: it worked great for my depression. A few months after starting
column4: I began to gain weight despite eating right. I have also been trying to quit smoking so my doctor switched me to Wellbutrin recently. I have not taken Cymbalta for a week now and I wish I would just not wake up. I had intense withdrawals from stopping Effexor XR in the past and hoped to never experience that again. My doctor told me to discontinue Cymbalta without weaning off. I will make it a point not to see him while I am going thru the withdrawals because I just might hurt him. I have never felt so awful in my life. I have severe brain zaps that have increased within the past week
column5: body aches
column6: chills
column7: visual disturbances
column8: dizziness
column9: extreme anger at any given moment
column10: extreme sadness at any given moment
column11: and thoughts of wanting to die. I have put my husband and children through hell the past week and from what I have read
column12: it will only get worse until my body is completely free of the drug. For anyone out there thinking of beginning an antidepressant
column13: read all you can about the drug including the withdrawal symptoms. I have taken at least six different antidepressants over the past 10 years and all of them worked
column14: but only for awhile. I work for a neurologist who treats fibromyalia and diabetic neuropathies and have seen patients who would rather deal with the pain than the side effects of Cymbalta. I think it is strange that the clinical trials and studies have not been published regarding Cymbalta. We are like lab rats enabling these pharmacutical companies to make a profit. Depression is something no one should have to deal with but honestly

column16: my family and friends have been there for me
column17: if not
column18: I wouldn't be here. Please research before starting any antidepressant. They only work for awhile and then you are left dealing with the horrific withdrawal symptoms.

4100$Major Depressive Disorder$4/15/2008 2:58:29 AM$Reviewer: bunzies, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $3$1$5$i have already made a couple of entries-going through withdrawls from this med-nausea, brain zaps, tremors, achiness, mood swings, etc..anyhow, i'd been trying to wean off cymbalta, -first from going from 60 every day, to 30 every day, then 30 every other day, etc..sick as a dog still,--saw my dr. today--he told me that the withdrawls from this drug, and most other drugs is six weeks from the last dose taken--i almost wish i had stopped cold turkey, because i've been feeling crazy and putrid for about eight weeks now, and still have six more to go--oh joy!! but he said i should feel alot better in a couple of weeks, and then keep improving--i find that when i read about everyone else having these withdrawl symptoms, its a bit easier, and then finding out that the mood swings are also common, is helping-am going to try hot baths, and i heard that niacin is helpful for detoxifying drug addicts, so will probably try that--i think the cymbalta may help some people--i thought it was good at first (took away cronic pain but didnt help depression), but then everything got worse, and i had pain everywhere, gained weight even though i eat hardly anything and am vegetarien and exersized, lost motivation for the things i used to like to do--even positive self talk didnt work--so for those of you who are having a wonderful time on this med, i hope you know that it has horrid withdrawl symptoms--i hear that cymbalta, effexor, and paxil have the worse withdrawl symptoms (from dr.) and that it is worse than heroin withdrawl, and believe me, they're not kidding--i wish i was warned about this before taking this drug--at one point i thought i was dying from something--i wish the best of luck to all of you that are withdrawing from this

4128$Major Depressive Disorder$4/5/2008 12:26:14 AM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more$1$1$5$i began taking this drug for depression, a couple of years ago-i felt ok at first, some pain i had from an injury went away,which helped me feel better emotionally (cronic pain sucks)--Then i started to feel worse-gained weight, became irritable, stressed out, unable to get out of bed-too tired, and was having horrible pain in my joints and back, making it hard for me to get out of bed physically, also--i decided to change to Wellbutrin, because i read that most people lose weight rather than gain it, and have discovered that since i've been weaning myself off cymbalta, that most of my pain is gone. of course, i also am having the disgusting withdrawl symptoms from cymbalta-nausea, vommiting, dizziness, electric zaps in my head(had those when i started cymbalta,also), --i began weaning off the cymbalta by going from 60mg to 30mgs every day, then 30mgs every other day, and now am trying 30 mgs every third day-i've been doing this for about 6 weeks now--am hoping to not be too nauseated tomorrow--last week skipped one extra day, and paid for it with nausea,..had to take a dose for 3 days straight--i don't think many drs know what this is like--they should recommend anyone wanting to get off cymbalta to go to a drug detox center, because it is a nightmare getting off of it--

column1: 4157$Major Depressive Disorder$3/26/2008 3:19:55 PM$Reviewer: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $3$1$1$I recommend that before you start this med that you ask your doctor for a blood test. I took the med and felt great
column2: took away neck and back pain immedietly. Then 4 weeks into it I felt hungry all the time and even after I ate a huge meal I would feel hungry. I stayed on the med for 5 months then just quit taking it because of the hunger and weight gain
column3: despite exercising an hour 5 days a week. The withdrawl was hell
column4: but what i didn't realize is that if you have blood sugar problems like I have (hypoglycemia) this med aggravated it and that is why I was hungry all the time and never felt full. Be sure to check thyroid first too because thyroid and depression symtoms are the same as was my case
column5: but didn't find that out until after going through the expense of the med and hell of the withdrawl.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $4$1$1$"Although the cymbalta did treat my depression to the point that I could function once again

column1: side effects. I am someone who actually reads the pamphlet that the pharmacist gives you.  No where to be found are the severe impact it can have on your weight. Over time
column2: and I have been on it approximately 18 months.  Upon further investigation on my part
column3: I have found that cymbalta actually enters your fat cells and STAYS THERE! OVER TIME the weight creeps on and on.  To top that off are the severe side effects when you are trying to ween yourself off of it.  For example
column4: I have  gained 15 POUNDS in the two weeks while trying to eliminate cymbalta from my life. Not to mention the other awful side effects: brain zaps
column5: mood swings
column6: high blood pressure
column7: urge to urinate one second & not making it to the bathroom the next
column8: diahrea
column9: joint pain
column10: brain fog
column11: adema
column12: slurred speech and others. Think twice before using this drug. In the 18 months that I have been taking it I have gained 34 pounds. On a 5'1"" frame thats another whole person practically. I was in a size 6-8 petite
column13: and now I am busting out size 16's.

column1: Talk about a reason to be depressed!!! It's been 17 days and the brain zaps are almost gone and I am ""starting"" to feel like myself again-except for the weight gain. If I was eating carbs
column2: sweets
column3: etc. that would be one thing. But I follow a high protein
column4: high vegetable diet.  Really consider the consequences."

It worked wonders for about 2 or 3 months. Since then I am living in my own HELL trying to get off of it. I recommend anyone that is thinking of trying this, PLEASE look it up online! I am not the only one going through this. The withdrawal symptoms are so severe I keep giving in and finally taking it again just to feel some relief. This time I am not going back. I want this horrible drug out of my system. When I was on it I couldn't sleep. I tried ambien and lunesta, and they didn't work. The withdawal symptoms include horrible physical pain and weakness, intense periods of depression and crying. Feeling like you are lost. If anyone has ever seen a Cymbalta commercial, thats exactly what you will feel like when you try to wean yourself off of it. I hope this can be helpful to anyone.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $4$4$4$I was diagnosed with major depression several years ago and was on just about every antidepressant out there over the years. I tried Elavil
column3: trazadone
column4: zoloft
column5: paxil
column6: prozac
column7: wellbutrin
column8: lexapro
column9: and effexor with no real help. I started taking Cymbalta and in less than 2 weeks
column10: I lost 12 pounds. I went into what was recognized by my doctor as a manic phase.I couldn't sleep at night
column11: which made the manic phase worse. My symptoms of rapid cycling lasted for about 6 weeks
column12: which can be exhausting when it's over. The ride back down is ten times worse than the depression I had been dealing with over the last few years.  I had only had an episode of mania once before this
column13: so with this second episode
column14: I was diagnosed with bipolar disorder. I used the websites tools to track my moods and meds. It is a very helpful tool to use to communicate with the doctor. This was the first medication that I used that helped my depression
column15: but be careful. If you are bipolar and don't know it
column16: this medication can really bring it on. Also
column17: be extra careful taking this medication with Ambien. I was on the two and started sleepwalking 4 or 5 nights a week. I also had very vivid nightmares and lots of waking up soaked in sweat. This is a very good medication when used appropriately. As with any medication like this
column18: give it at least 3 weeks before deciding it is not working.

In the beginning things seemed to be progressing decently but they have steadily declined ever since though my dosage is constantly increased.  The drug isn't difficult so much to take.  I'm disgruntled and say it's hard to use because of the stupid way they've got me set up on it.  I'm at 180mg a day: 120 in the morning and 60 at night.  It would have been much easier to give me a huge bottle of 60mg'ers and take 2 in the morning... but
column3: NO.  So now
column4: for bacially one prescribed drug I have two separate prescriptions: 120mg and 60mg: paying twice for what I should only have to pay once.  Ripoff!

column1: At this point I'd rather go back to my old AD
column2: Celexa.  No
column3: that didn't work either (obvious due the change to Cymbalta) but at least I didn't have the dosage/prescription hassle.

column2: or may not
column3: have also contributed to a definitive spike in my anxiety
column4: psychosis
column5: and paranoia.  As the Cymbalta increased
column6: Seroquel also became necessary to take (yet another drug that also isn't working... got a post there too).

column1: Many times I feel like I'd rather just not have any at all.  Sure
column2: nothing would be better but at this point I wouldn't be any worse off.  And at the very least I'd not be paying for overpriced medication that hasn't done anything more than a glass of water can do!"
